results.title: Beds and appliances
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Care of the sick and injured”.
This film, produced by the U.S. Navy, demonstrates how to make and manipulate beds for the sick and injured (particularly those bedridden for extended periods of time) so that the patient’s comfort is increased and their recovery is thereby quickened. Demonstrates how to make a bunk as well as a bed in a ward so that the bedclothes do no need adjusting during the day, and also includes handy tips for materials which can be used to improvise elevations and inclines to vary a patient’s position in bed. No other credits available.

results.title: Bedrooms and hallways [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rose Troche, Dorothy Berwin, Ceci Dempsey and Berwin and Dempsey Productions
results.brief_description: Rose Troche’s (“Go Fish”) second feature film is a gentle and amusing study into the nuances of sexual preference, dating and masculinity. Using Leo’s (Kevin McKidd) 30th birthday bash as a basis, the film traces Leo’s relationship to the guests; gay room mate Darren (Tom Hollander) and his real estate agent boyfriend (Hugo Weaving) with a penchant for using the bedrooms of the houses he’s selling for their trysts; straight and single friend Angie (Julie Graham); new Age guru and leader of Leo’s men’s group, Keith (Simon Callow); Leo’s previous boyfriend, Brendan (James Purefoy) and Brendan’s current girlfriend, Sally (Jennifer Ehle), who also happens to be Leo’s high school sweetheart. Central to the film are the gatherings of the men’s group for masculine assertiveness and when Leo admits his attraction to seemingly straight, Irishman Brendan, it opens the floodgates for other members of the group with surprising results. (Awards: Winner Audience Award, London Film Festival, 1998)

results.title: Bedouins of Arabia
results.creator_credit: Richard Taylor and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: Portrays the life of Bedouin tribesmen in the Arabian desert, noting their relationships with each other and with the land. Suitable for upper primary and secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Bedlam  for Spectrum 128 & +2
results.creator_credit: GO! Media Holdings Ltd and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Bedlam [computer game]. Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

results.title: Bedlam
results.creator_credit: Mark Robson, Val Lewton and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: A dramatic and sinister psychodrama from horror film producer Val Lewton, who was also responsible for bringing classics such as “Cat people” (1942), “The Leopard man” (1943), “The Ghost ship” (1943), “The Body snatcher” (1945) and “Isle of the dead” (1945) to the big screen. In 18th century London, paradoxically named the Age of Reason by the people, a popular past-time for upper classes was to visit St. Mary’s of Bethlehem Asylum - “Bedlam” - to observe its “loonies”. After the death of a young poet attempting to escape Bedlam leaves the wealthy Lord Mortimer without a commissioned play, the sinister head of the Asylum, Master George Sims, steps in and offers to stage a mask performed by the inmates of his Asylum. Intrigued, Mortimer’s young protege Mistress Nell Bowen decides to pay the Asylum a visit, but becomes rapidly disgusted and offended by Sims’ brutal and sadistic treatment of the inmates. With advice from Quaker stonemason William Hannay, she resolves to stop the mistreatment and bring about reform. However, her plans go awry when Sims manages to turn Lord Mortimer against her, and then has her committed to Bedlam. Shunned by those whom she once called friends, Nell finds friendship and hope among the tortured souls imprisoned in the madhouse, and her quest to reform the system becomes more urgent. However, the inmates have their own ideas about reform, and justice is served to their cruel tormentor in a most macabre manner, in a scene lifted from Edgar Allen Poe. Fascinating to note is that one of the reasons given as to why a particular inmate was confined, was due to his desire to create ‘moving pictures’. Bedlam, written by Lewton under a pseudonym and inspired by William Hogarth’s satirical series of engravings entitled, “A Rakes’s Progress” (1735), represents a marked shift away from the sensationalist b-movies he produced in the early 40’s , and was his last offering in the horror genre before his death in 1951. Cast includes Boris Karloff, Anna Lee.

results.title: Bedknobs and broomsticks
results.brief_description: Angela Lansbury plays a prim and proper Eglantine Price, an amateur English witch who joins up with three cockney waifs to help save war-torn Britain from Nazi invaders. A film for all ages, Bedknobs and Broomsticks features ingenious animation, a hilarious soccer game where crocodiles, elephants, and other animals really kick up a storm. Brass beds fly, nightgowns dance, and airborne brooms sweep away young and old alike to a fun-filled world of fantasy.

results.title: BeDevil
results.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt, Carol Hughes, Anthony Buckley and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: BeDevil is an astounding work of Australian cinema which combines iconography drawn from Aboriginal culture and mythology, urban Australia, and popular culture. Comprising three ghost stories, all of which deal with the nature of memory and loss, this film playfully subverts the conventional linkings between aboriginality and spirituality. In “Mr. Chuck” the ghost of a US soldier haunts a billabong. In “Choo Choo Choo Choo” Ruby, (played by director Tracey Moffatt), and her family are haunted by an invisible train. In the final story, “Lovin’ The Spin I’m In”, a grieving Islander mother and her Greek-Australian neighbours are under the spell of the ghostly lovers, Bebe and Minnie. Drawing from influences that span across Aboriginal culture, American and European film, television amd popular culture, “BeDevil” announces the birth of a new kind of Australian cinema: both indigenous and multicultural; mystical and sophisticated; innovative and pleasurable. The intoxicating cinematography is by Academy-award winning Geoff Burton and the music score is by Carl Vine. Visually stunning and metaphorically rich, this is a wonderful film.

results.title: Bed and board = Domicile conjugal
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, Marcel Berbert, Valoria, Films du Carrosse and Fida Cinematografica
results.brief_description: Fourth instalment in Francois Truffaut’s “Antoine Doinel” series depicts the still somewhat immature Antoine facing the birth of his first child, infatuation with a Japanese woman and the petty squabbles of married life. Whilst perhaps not as well realised as “Stolen kisses”, “Bed and board” nevertheless maintains a laconic charm, aided by the redoubtable Truffaut mainstay, Jean-Pierre Leaud.

results.title: Becoming me
results.creator_credit: Tyson Cunningham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Tyson Cunningham can’t express himself, music does it for him. Although he has long given up dreams of fronting a band like his brother, music is still everything to him, and expresses his emotional life like nothing else.
